name: Introduction to Philosophy
prerequisites: Credit is not allowed for both PHI 205 and PHI 210.
descripton: Introduction to selected problems of enduring philosophical importance, including such topics as the nature of morality, knowledge, human freedom, and the existence of God. Content varies with different sections.

name: Representation, Reason and Reality
prerequisites: Credit is not allowed for both PHI 210 and PHI 205
descripton: This course is an introduction to philosophical issues concerning topics such as language, thought, knowledge, reason, truth, and reality through the study of problems, puzzles, and paradoxes. Not both PHI 205 and PHI 210 may be used towards satisfaction on PHI major or PHI minor requirements.

name: Issues in Business Ethics
descripton: An analysis and evaluation of major issues in business ethics.  Topics include the social responsibility of business; social justice and free enterprise; the rights and duties of employers, employees, manufacturers, and consumers; duties to the environment, the world's poor, future generations, and the victims of past injustices; the moral status of the corporation; and the ethics of advertising.

name: Contemporary Moral Issues
descripton: Philosophical analysis and theory applied to a broad range of contemporary moral issues, including euthanasia, suicide, capital punishment, abortion, war, famine relief, and environmental concerns.

name: Thinking Logically
descripton: Deductive arguments attempt to guarantee their conclusions. Inductive arguments attempt to make their conclusions more probable. Using a small number of simple, powerful logical techniques, this course teaches you how to find, analyze and evaluate deductive and inductive arguments, and thus how to avoid the most common errors in reasoning.

name: Special Topics in Philosophy
descripton: Selected studies in philosophy that do not appear regularly in the curriculum. Topics will be announced for each semester in which the course is offered.

name: Ancient Philosophy
descripton: Western philosophy of the ancient world, with special emphasis on Plato and Aristotle.

name: Early Modern Philosophy
descripton: Western philosophy of the 17th and 18th centuries, including such philosophers as Descartes, Hobbes, Leibniz, Locke, Berkeley, Hume, and Kant.

name: 19th Century Philosophy
descripton: Western philosophy of the 19th century, including such philosophers as Kant, Hegel, Schopenhauer, Kierkegaard, Marx, and Nietzsche.

name: Philosophy of Religion
descripton: The existence and nature of God, including such topics as traditional proofs of God, skeptical challenges to religious belief, miracles, the problem of evil, faith and reason, and religious experience.

name: Contemporary Political Philosophy
prerequisites: Prerequisite: One PHI course
descripton: Current theories about basic concepts in political philosophy, such as liberty, equality, justice, natural rights, and democracy, with special attention to disputes concerning the nature of a just social order.

name: Existentialism
descripton: Philosophy of Existentialism, including such thinkers as Kierkegaard, Nietzsche, Doestoevsky, Sartre, Heidegger, and Camus.

name: Philosophy of Law
descripton: Fundamental legal issues such as what constitutes a law or legal system.  Justifications of legal interference with individual liberty. Philosophical legal issues illustrated by specific legal cases.

name: Ethical Problems in the Law
prerequisites: Prerequisite: PHI 221, 275, or 375
descripton: Explores uses of the legal system, including such topics as the death penalty, plea bargaining, legalizing euthanasia, censorship, Good Samaritan laws, the insanity defense, civil disobedience, preferential treatment.

name: Bio-Medical Ethics
descripton: Interdisciplinary examination and appraisal of emerging ethical and social issues resulting from recent advances in the biological and medical sciences. Abortion, euthanasia, physician-assisted suicide, compromised infants, aids, reproductive technologies, and health care. Focus on factual details and value questions, fact-value questions, fact-value interplay, and questions of impact assessment and policy formulation.

name: Metaphysics
prerequisites: Prerequisite: One PHI course
descripton: Metaphysical problems: distinction between appearance and reality, nature of space and time, free will and determinism, mind and body, nature of identity.

name: Philosophy of Language
prerequisites: Prerequisite: One PHI course
descripton: Introduction to traditional and modern accounts of the relations between language and reality, the nature of truth, problems of intentionality and propositional attitudes.

name: Philosophy of Psychology
prerequisites: Prerequisite: One PHI course or one PSY course
descripton: Problems and controversies that overlap the boundary between philosophy and psychology: the mind/body problem, behaviorism vs. cognitivism, the prospects for artificial intelligence, and language and the questions of innate knowledge.

name: Theory of Knowledge
prerequisites: Prerequisite: One PHI course
descripton: Analysis of such central concepts as knowledge, belief, and truth, and the investigation of the principles by which claims to knowledge may be justified.

name: Philosophy of Science
descripton: Nature of science highlighted by differences between science and pseudoscience, relationships between science and religion, and roles of purpose-directed (teleological) and causal explanation in physical, life and social sciences.

name: Ethics
descripton: Examination of traditional questions of philosophical ethics: What are the principles of moral conduct?  What sort of life is worthy of a human being?  Includes both classic and contemporary literature.

name: History of Ethics
prerequisites: Prerequisite: One PHI course
descripton: Topics in the history of ethics.  Philosophers to be studied may include Plato, Aristotle, Aquinas, Butler, Hume, Kant, Sidgwick and Nietzsche.

name: Kant's Critique of Pure Reason
prerequisites: Prerequisite: 6 credits in PHI. Credit is not allowed for both PHI 401 and PHI 501.
descripton: A text-based critical study of Kant's Critique of Pure Reason Focusing on such topics as perception, judgment, knowledge, space, time, substance, causation and reality.  Students cannot receive credit for both PHI 401 and PHI 501.

name: Life Science Ethics
prerequisites: Prerequisite: One PHI course
descripton: Recent work in normative evaluation of human actions affecting living things.  Advanced readings in moral theory, comparative value assessment, and public policy. Students cannot receive credit for both PHI 415 and PHI 515.

name: Global Justice
prerequisites: Prerequisite: One PHI course. Credit is not allowed for both PHI 420 and PHI 520.
descripton: The applications of the ideas of justice and right beyond and across the borders of individual nation states, attending to the facts of globalization and their consequences for political and economic justice and human rights. Topics: skepticism about global justice; transnational distributive justice, pollution, and poverty; national sovereignty, self-determination, and intervention; the ethics of war; international human rights; and global democracy. No one can receive credit for both PHI 420 and PHI 520.

name: Philosophical Issues in Environmental Ethics
prerequisites: Prerequisite: One PHI course
descripton: Ethical questions about the environment; in particular, what obligations we have to the environment.  Topics: animal rights, obligations to species and ecosystems, intrinsic vs. extrinsic value, and policy implications of moral judgments. Students cannot receive credit for both PHI 422 and PHI 522. Students who have received credit for PHI 322 cannot receive credit for either PHI 422 or PHI 522.

name: Introduction to Cognitive Science
prerequisites: Prerequisite: One upper-level PHI, PSY, CSC or Linguistics course. Credit is not allowed for PHI 425 and PHI/PSY 525.
descripton: Philosophical foundations and empirical fundamentals of cognitive science, an interdisciplinary approach to human cognition. Topics include: the computational model of mind, mental representation, cognitive architecture, the acquisition and use of language.  Students cannot receive credit for both PHI/PSY 425 and PHI/PSY 525.

name: The Scientific Method
prerequisites: Prerequisite: One upper-level PHI course. Credit is not allowed for both PHI 440 and PHI 540.
descripton: Detailed examination of core issues in the philosophy of science: the confirmation of scientific theories, falsification, projectibility, the nature of scientific explanation, laws of nature, and causation. Students cannot receive credit for both PHI 440 and PHI 540.

name: Philosophy, Evolution and Human Nature
prerequisites: Prerequisite: One 300 level or higher course in Philosophy, Biology, Psychology or Anthropology. Credit is not allowed for PHI 447 and PHI 557.
descripton: This course covers philosophical issues in the evolutionary study of human cognition: the role of adaptationism; the values of psychological vs. behavioral approaches; the phenotypic gambit; the evolution of morality and altruism; the nature of culture and the possibility of cultural evolution; innateness, genetic determinism and development; and case studies of evolutionary explanation of human behavior or psychology.  Students cannot receive credit for both PHI 447 and PHI 547.

name: Ethical Theory
prerequisites: Prerequisite: PHI 375 or PHI 376. Credit is not allowed for both PHI 475 and PHI 575.
descripton: An introduction to some central themes and issues in ethical theory.  Topics in normative and meta-ethics such as consequentialism, deontology, virtue ethics, constructivism, realism, relativism, subjectivism, and expressivism. Readings primarily from contemporary literature.

name: Research and Writing in Ethics
descripton: A substantial paper in ethics, assigned by the instructor of the corequisite; enrollment subject to departmental approval; may be repeated for credit.

name: Research and Writing in History of Philosophy
prerequisites: Prerequisite: PHI 250, LOG 201 or 335 and one other PHI course, Corequisite: One of PHI 298, 300, 301, 302, 303, 310, 401 or 498
descripton: A substantial paper in history of philosophy, assigned by the instructor of the corequisite; enrollment subject to departmental approval; may be repeated or credit.

name: Research and Writing in Contemporary Philosophy
prerequisites: Prerequisite: PHI 250, LOG 201 or 335 and one other PHI course, Corequisite: One of PHI 298, 305, 306, 330, 331, 332, 333, 340, 425, 440, 445, 447 or 498
descripton: A substantial paper in contemporary philosophy, assigned by the instructor of the corequisite; enrollment subject to departmental approval; may be repeated for credit.

name: Research and Writing in Logic, Representation and Reasoning
prerequisites: Prerequisite: LOG 201 or 335, and one other PHI course, not PHI 250, Corequisite: One of LOG 335, 435/535, 437, PHI 298, 330, 331, 332, 333, 340, 425/525, 440/540, 445/545, 447
descripton: A substantial paper in logic, representation and reasoning, assigned by the instructor of the corequisite. enrollment subject to departmental approval; may be repeated for credit

name: Special Topics in Philosophy
prerequisites: Prerequisite: Six credits in PHI courses
descripton: Detailed investigation of selected topics in  philosophy. Topics determined by faculty members in consultation with head of the department. Course may be used for individualized study.

prerequisites: Prerequisite: Graduate standing
descripton: Detailed investigation of selected advanced topics in philosophy. Topics determined by faculty members in consultation with head of department.

name: Introduction to Research Ethics
prerequisites: Prerequisite: Graduate standing
descripton: Institutional rules guiding the responsible conduct of research (RCR) and their philosophical justification.  Rudiments of moral reasoning and their application to RCR.  Topics: plagiarism, falsification and fabrication of data, and ethics versus custom, law, science, and religion.
